topics.title: Normal Intubation

content.definition: A device that covers the nose and mouth to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
content.uses: Preoxygenation, oxygenation during short procedures, or in emergency resuscitation.
content.indications: Respiratory distress, preoxygenation before intubation, conscious sedation.
content.contraindications: Facial trauma, inability to maintain airway.
content.pediatric_dose: Adjusted by size; pediatric masks are available.

content.definition: A flexible plastic tube inserted into the trachea to maintain a patent airway.
content.uses: Mechanical ventilation, general anesthesia, airway protection.
content.indications: Respiratory failure, surgery requiring GA, airway obstruction.
content.contraindications: Upper airway pathology, relative in facial trauma (consider alternative airway).
content.effects: Secures airway, allows for controlled ventilation.

content.definition: Curved plastic device to keep the airway open by preventing the tongue from covering the epiglottis.
content.indications: Airway obstruction due to tongue, during bag-valve-mask ventilation.
content.contraindications: Conscious or semi-conscious patients (risk of gagging/vomiting).
content.sizing: Measured from corner of mouth to angle of mandible.

content.definition: A soft rubber/plastic tube inserted through the nostril into the nasopharynx.
content.uses: Semi-conscious patients with intact gag reflex.
content.indications: Upper airway obstruction, during bagging where OPA isn’t tolerated.
content.size_selection: Based on diameter (usually 6–7 mm ID in adults); length from nose to earlobe.

content.definition: An instrument used to visualize the larynx for intubation.
content.pediatric_considerations: Miller blades more common in neonates/infants.

flashcards.answer: Preoxygenation and oxygenation during short procedures.

drugs.name: Propofol
drugs.mechanism: Global CNS inhibition, likely through potentiation of GABA-A receptor activity.
drugs.indications: Induction and maintenance of general anesthesia, sedation.
drugs.contraindications: Allergy to propofol, egg or soy products.

drugs.name: Aspirin
drugs.mechanism: Irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes.
drugs.indications: Pain, fever, inflammation, prevention of blood clots.
